text: I’d say it’s going to be different anywhere you work. Some companies are very encouraging and even let you contribute to open source as apart of your day-to-day work (I’ve been able to do some of this at Domo). But other places have very strict guidelines on that kind of stuff. Usually if it’s off company time and not directly related to your day job, I’d guess most companies wouldn’t mind.

text: I mean, at places like Invenia and Beacon, there’s some possibility to open source work because it’s really in the best interest of the company. By open sourcing, they can collaborate w/ other companies and users to help improve code, while keeping their “secret sauce” code private obviously. But there’s a lot of more infrastructure type things that can really benefit from being open sourced. I was able to do a lot of the heavy work on HTTP.jl while working at Domo because we needed a solid webstack for the things we were doing and they were ok with open sourcing the work to get more people to help.

text: <@U0138UTB7A4> ask if your workplace has a written policy for open source contribution. Most contracts state that your employer owns any IP you develop as an employee. Some even say IP you create outside of work belongs to them too. Most likely, you'll need some sort of intellectual property disclaimer or transfer to contribute to open source.

text: I find the aversion to open source and demand for off-the-clock inventions weird too, tbh.  It’s like none of those companies realize we code for fun and want to be left alone to do it.  Unless the software itself is the product (as in games, tools, and models) a software business’ sustainable cash flow comes from scaling, management, tech support, updates, customization, and security.

text: It also depends on the jurisdiction you are in. Moonlighting / personal time IP ownership laws vary quite a bit in different US states, for example. You also need to make sure you don’t do work you want to own on company property, unless specifically authorized that you own such work (and even then it might be a bad idea. because the situation will be different if using a corporate laptop even on personal time in an otherwise firewalled jurisdiction).
